title: Fetal and neonatal hematopoietic progenitors are functionally and transcriptionally resistant to <italic>Flt3-</italic>ITD mutations
abstract: The <italic>FLT3</italic> Internal Tandem Duplication (<italic>FLT3</italic>) mutation is common in adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) but rare in early childhood AML. It is not clear why this difference occurs. Here we show that <italic>Flt3</italic> and cooperating <italic>Flt3/Runx1</italic> mutations cause hematopoietic stem cell depletion and myeloid progenitor expansion during adult but not fetal stages of murine development. In adult progenitors, FLT3<sup>ITD</sup> simultaneously induces self-renewal and myeloid commitment programs via STAT5-dependent and STAT5-independent mechanisms, respectively. While FLT3<sup>ITD</sup> can activate STAT5 signal transduction prior to birth, this signaling does not alter gene expression until hematopoietic progenitors transition from fetal to adult transcriptional states. Cooperative interactions between <italic>Flt3</italic> and <italic>Runx1</italic> mutations are also blunted in fetal/neonatal progenitors. Fetal/neonatal progenitors may therefore be protected from leukemic transformation because they are not competent to express FLT3<sup>ITD</sup> target genes. Changes in the transcriptional states of developing hematopoietic progenitors may generally shape the mutation spectra of human leukemias.
